name: spatialdata

variants.name: build_system
variants.description: Build systems supported by the package

description:
SpatialData provides an interface to Proj.4 for converting coordinates
Spatialdata is a C++ library for interpolating values for spatially
distributed data, converting coordinates among geographic projections
using Proj, nondimensionalization of quantities, specification of units
via Pyre (optional). This library is used in the finite-element code
PyLith (https://github.com/geodynamics/pylith). The primary focus is
specification of parameters that vary in space, such as values for
boundary conditions and parameters of constitutive models. This provides
a specification of these parameters independent of the discretization.

dependencies.name: autoconf
dependencies.description: Autoconf -- system configuration part of autotools

dependencies.name: automake
dependencies.description: Automake -- make file builder part of autotools

dependencies.name: gmake
dependencies.description:
GNU Make is a tool which controls the generation of executables and
other non-source files of a program from the program's source files.

dependencies.name: gnuconfig
dependencies.description:
The GNU config.guess and config.sub scripts versioned by timestamp.
This package can be used as a build dependency for autotools packages
that ship a tarball with outdated config.guess and config.sub files.

dependencies.name: libtool
dependencies.description: libtool -- library building part of autotools.

dependencies.name: m4
dependencies.description: GNU M4 is an implementation of the traditional Unix macro processor.

dependencies.name: proj
dependencies.description:
PROJ is a generic coordinate transformation software, that transforms
geospatial coordinates from one coordinate reference system (CRS) to
another. This includes cartographic projections as well as geodetic
transformations.

dependencies.name: py-cig-pythia
dependencies.description:
This is the Computational Infrastructure for Geodynamics (CIG) fork of
Pythia/Pyre originally written by Michael Aivazis (California Institute
of Technology). Pythia/Pyre provides a Python framework for scientific
simulations. This fork focuses (and maintains) functionality for:
specification of simulation parameters specification of units and unit
conversions user-friendly interface to popular batch job schedulers
Python and C++ interfaces for logging

dependencies.name: py-numpy
dependencies.description: Fundamental package for array computing in Python.

dependencies.name: py-setuptools
dependencies.description:
A Python utility that aids in the process of downloading, building,
upgrading, installing, and uninstalling Python packages.

dependencies.name: swig
dependencies.description:
SWIG is an interface compiler that connects programs written in C and
C++ with scripting languages such as Perl, Python, Ruby, and Tcl. It
works by taking the declarations found in C/C++ header files and using
them to generate the wrapper code that scripting languages need to
access the underlying C/C++ code. In addition, SWIG provides a variety
of customization features that let you tailor the wrapping process to
suit your application.

dependent_to.name: py-pylith
dependent_to.description:
PyLith does dynamic and quasi-static simulations of crustal deformation.
PyLith is an open-source finite-element code for dynamic and quasi-
static simulations of crustal deformation, primarily earthquakes and
volcanoes.
